name: Mercure Tokyo Ginza

reviews.text: I really enjoyed my stay at the Mercure Ginza. This is a quiet hotel just off the main Ginza-dori, quite a charming area with small boutiques, coffee shops and a fruit stand on the block. Subway station accessible from the basement level. The staff were courteous, my room was very clean and a decent size by Tokyo standards. Very comfortable mattress. Good breakfast buffet. I have stayed at more expensive hotels in Tokyo, but prefer the Mercure Ginza.
reviews.title: Great choice

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We had a very enjoyable stay. The room was a good size, clean and tastefully decorated. Good location for shopping within the Ginza district of Tokyo. Very convenient to travel elsewhere with easy access to the trains. We would recommend it.
reviews.title: Good choice

likes.liked: — Reasonably big room, clean & good location.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I booked this hotel room as part of a package. I read the reviews on this site and thought it was a good bet. When I booked it I strongly requested a non-smoking room.
reviews.title: Good three star but beware of smoking rooms
Perfect location for shoppers
reviews.text: When we checked in I asked whether this had been honoured and the woman on the front desk assured me we were in a nonsmoking room on a non-smoking floor.
We went to the room (on the 3rd floor) and everything was good. Clean, comfy bed, nice bathroom. The room is very small but adequate for 3 star.
reviews.title: Great value for central Tokyo

reviews.text: The next day however, things started to go bad. They only give you the bare minimum, one towel each, they don't replace the used shampoo and I had to ask for it. The TV has only 1 English channel (CNN). I am not there for the TV by any means but it is nice to watch a bit before going to sleep of a night.
reviews.title: Wonderful place!

reviews.text: I stayed in the Mercure Ginza twice during our trip to Japan. Overall it was a great choice. You can tell it was cozy no-frills style accommodation, yet it has everything you need with great service.
reviews.title: Don't expect Ginza-like oppulance but still worth it

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: ROOMS
reviews.title: Great Location for the price.

reviews.text: I booked a queen bed room which had no view (unless looking into the office building windows next door counts as a view). The bed was comfy, small but adequete storage space and desk area, which was a real surprise considering the amount of luggage I had (skis and ski boots). The bathroom amenities provided were more than enough. The only thing that needed getting used to were the lighting system and how to use the hot and cold taps in the shower. Luckily commonsense prevailed within a few hours of checking in!
reviews.title: More than you pay for

reviews.text: PUBLIC AREAS
reviews.title: Great location

reviews.text: Don't expect someone to help you with your bags and ensure you dont leave anything behind as the reception desk is on the 2nd floor. The second time I stayed, the staff offered to carry our bags downstairs- I wasn't sure why as they never bothered the first time round. All staff have good English and were very helpful with Limosuine bus transfers and taxi pick ups etc. They were also helpful in letting us store some of our luggage while we went to other parts of Japan till our return. There is one computer that has free Wi-fi access just outside the only restaurant in the hotel. I didn't use the restaurant as there was a Maccas (and the rest of Tokyo for that matter) under the building and the menu looked a little pricey.
reviews.title: Centrally located

reviews.text: Our family ( me, my husband and our 3 kids) stayed at this hotel in July 2006 and again in February 2007 as part of our visit to the Sapporo Snow Festival in Hokkaido. The hotel is in a great location where we can walk about 10 mins from the nearest JR station where we got off the Narita express.
reviews.title: Perfect location, great staff and good value for money.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The underground metro station is just at the corner of the hotel. Although, the underground metro is a bit more expensive than the JR, we found that it's more convenient for our family which have 3 small kids (age 9, 6 and 4) as it's station is less crowded than the JR's. From the hotel, it is also a short walk to the other underground station which we took the train to Haneda airport for a flight to Hokkaido.
reviews.title: Great stay in Ginza at Mercure

reviews.text: We booked connecting rooms. Rooms are nice, clean and very small. Anyway, we understand that this is Ginza (the most expensive area of Tokyo).
reviews.title: Heated toilet seats - thumbs up

reviews.text: The most impressing thing about the hotel is its staffs. Before my trip started, I had booked a hotel in Hokkaido with one of the Japanese website which I used for the first time. I was not sure about the booking so I emailed Mercure Ginza asking for some suggestions. Without my request, one of the staff had called the hotel in Hokkaido and confirmed everything for us. This is really impressed me. I plan to go to Japan again next year for Tateyama - Japan Alps and will definetly stay at the Mercure Ginza Hotel again as part of the trip.
reviews.title: Great location, great hotel ......

likes.liked: — Everything with this hotel was excellent
likes.disliked: — Too bad it is not a little bit bigger with more facilities

reviews.text: We stayed at the Mercure Ginza July 12-18, 2007. This great little hotel is tucked away behind the Matsuya Department Store just off the main Ginza St. Rooms are compact, yet highly functional and comfortable. We were on the 8th floor, and it was very quiet. Easy to walk to all great Ginza shopping, and to the Tokyo Station. Great rates, and their breakfast is filling and has lots of choices, Western or Japanese! Can't go wrong here.
reviews.title: Accor's secret

likes.disliked: — hard to find for taxi drivers

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: This is not a full service hotel, as this is rare in Japan. You will not have someone to carry bags or wait on you hand and foot in your room. This can be had in Tokyo, but at an extreme price, certainly far above what the very reasonable Mercure charges.
reviews.title: An excellent choice for Tokyo explorers..

reviews.text: That said, this business/leisure hotel is in one of the most expensive shopping areas of Tokyo (without the usual corresponding prices for the rooms) and you can expect a beautifuly quiet night's sleep here without traffic or train noise interrupting. The Subway is at the end of the street (50 meters) or you can jump the JR line with another 2 minutes walk. Ginza Dori is only 2 short blocks away for a little shopping. Tokyo station (take the Narita Express in from the airport to here) is only 700 yen by taxi, door to door.
reviews.title: Great Location for shopping in Ginza

reviews.text: The rooms are small, but not by Japanese standards. They are welll fitted out and pleasant on the eye, not to mention, spotlessly clean of course. Free internet in the rooms is standard (are you listening Paris!!!), as are the local English newspapers.
reviews.title: Perfect location

likes.liked: — clean and tidy atmosphere good conviinient location

reviews.text: The staff were fantastic - all spoke good English, knew the area well and were only too happy to recommend restaurants, nightlife and touring spots. They also helped on the phone talking to the taxi driver so he could find the place from Tokyo station! Good food is available all around the area and you need only walk 10 paces before another Izakaya or food store comes into view from the hotel's front door. A comprehensive gaijin styled breakfast is available at the 2nd floor restaurant for a reasonable price each morning, if you get sick of rice and uncooked eggs.
reviews.title: Good location. Great service.

reviews.text: A great central base to explore the whole of Tokyo.
reviews.title: Great location - would recommend

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The Mercure Ginza was quite hard to find in the Ginza area of Tokyo as all the streets do not run in numerical order, however, once found it was more than adequate. The rooms were small but had everything you need, including the all singing, all dancing japanese tiolet that even had heating! A great feature was that you did not have to go through the lobby everytime you went out, as the lobby was situated on the 2nd floor. Security was good as you had to put your room key into a slot to go higher in the lift to your room. The breakfast was buffet style and had everything from rice to muffins. Only objection I would point out would be the area the hotel is in - Ginza is very westernised and has mostly department stores and big grand names such as Cartier, so if you're looking for a 'japanese experience' this wouldn't suit. In saying that, the way the bathrooms are set up in your room is very japanese - sliding doors made from glass in panels and they provide the traditional japanese robes. The rooms were clean and had tea making equipment, tv etc. The bed was very comfortable. The views were of other office/shop skyscrapers.
reviews.title: Great, if small hotel

reviews.text: All in all, I probably would use this hotel again.
reviews.title: Faultless, good value, v. central location

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Immaculately kept, modern hotel in great location right in the heart of Ginza. We stayed in a double room with 2 queen sized beds and though not large, the room was perfectly adequate and cleaned everyday to perfection. Trendy loo and excellent power shower over the bath, freebies in room and mini-bar with enough room for your own water and food. Very cheap local calls from the room phone was re-assuring when I got the bill. Very varied Eastern and Western buffet breakfast from 6.30- at least 10am is good for the jet-lag and was included in our room-rate. Didn't eat in the hotel otherwise - just so many other places to choose from. All the staff are bi-lingual and very friendly. This was our first trip to Japan and I will stay at the hotel again.
reviews.title: Wonderful Location and Reasonably Priced!
Great little hotel
reviews.text: Ginza is rather like the Bond Street area - smart shops and boutiques but not very cutting edge. Hotel within 15 min walk of Tokyo Station or short taxi ride. Ask hotel to give you directions back to hotel in Japanese ( even print a map to the hotel before you leave) and print out maps in Japanese as taxi drivers rarely speak any English and certainly don't read it and they don't map-read very well - even with Japanese maps but v. friendly. We took JR Line train from Narita Airport which was superb, v.efficient -just under 1 hr from Airport terminal. Hope you enjoy your trip as much as us.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: This hotel is in the perfect location....in the nice shopping and restaurant area of Ginza and walkable to the Tokyo Train Station. Tokyo can be so expensive and so this reasonably priced hotel in such a great location is a jewel. The rooms are not huge but are definitely large enough so you don't feel like you are in a closet. We stayed 2 nights and then went to Kyoto for one night and returned to this hotel for our last night in Tokyo. When we returned for the last night, the check-in person upgraded our room to a larger room which was a nice surprise. There is a computer next to the restaurant for free internet access. Lots of coffee shops nearby for breakfast. Would definitely recommend this to our friends.
reviews.title: fantastic hotel......when we eventually found it!

likes.disliked: — not in a touristy area (but that might have been a good thing?)

reviews.text: My family of 3 adults and a 16 year old stayed in 2 adjacent rooms on the 9th floor of the Ginza Mercure this week. We found the rooms to be a reasonable size for Tokyo, fitting two suitcases each with room to spare. The beds were comfortable, rooms very clean and quiet and bathrooms well sized. The restaurant is basic but provided an adequate breakfast. Free broadband using provided ethernet cable was excelent. We would recommend this hotel to you!
reviews.title: Great location, English speaking staff, good rooms! Tokyo travel tips here.

reviews.text: We travelled into Tokyo via the Narita Express. Purchased "Green" reserved seats and a Suica pass each through the JR office which is easy to find. The unreserved seats would be fine to purchase but as we had flown from Sydney the larger more comfortable seats of the Green reserved carriage were preferred. JR have an excellent website. Print off the map to make your way around the terminal easier.
reviews.title: Great hotel but make sure you know the address

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: From Tokyo station we caught 2 taxis (4 people + 4 suitacses and hand luggage would not fit into one taxi) to the hotel. I had the name and address printed off in Japanese for the drivers as they do not speak english. The fare was about YEN800 for ne of us and YEN950 for the other!
reviews.title: Fantastic Location, Great Value!

reviews.text: When we left Tokyo ecaught the TCAT bus to the terminal which was really straight forward and easy. The hotel booked us 4 seats which we paid for at the hotel and were given vouchers. We caught 2 taxis to the TCAT terminal and traded the vouchers for tickets. At our departure time there were plenty of seats on the bus and the trip took about an hour straight to Terminal 2.
reviews.title: Great location and comfortable stay

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We had a Tokyo Free Guide on the first day of our stay which was marvellous! Having a guide helped us orientate ourselves and we learnt how to use the subway system so that on day 2 we were able to get around ourselves. Look up their website and book early.
reviews.title: GOOD

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Hotel central for the shopping district of Ginza and the local attractions.Located in nice quiet street and you can gain access to hotel from subway direct to hotel reception.Free internet access as internet cafes quite scarse.Good room size but no drawers for clothing.Bathroom very good size and modern.Room had beautiful decor,very quite hotel never heard any neighbours in other rooms.
reviews.title: Fab location
Basic Very Clean Helpful
reviews.text: Excellent location for the price, walk straight out to Ginza shopping district. Expect Ginza to be like any shopping highstreet - as close to paris or London in shopping choice, not as nice as Michigan Av Chicargo IL. Very Spectacular when lit at night.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Hotel staff very polite helpful, room upgrade given as we had large luggage and a stroller, however extra £20 added to have a bed for little one - despite having booked this - advised no way H&S would allow extra bed in first room. Bathrooms clean lots of towels/toiletries. Small - but more space than we were expecting for the money. Hotel restuarant was OK not great - very strange take on French Food (not really remotely french)
reviews.title: Excellent hotel; stunning location!

reviews.text: Use the coach service to the airport terminal in the centre of Tokyo to get out to the airport - cheap regular and runs ontime.
reviews.title: great location

reviews.text: Our stay at the Mercure was excellent. The rooms are a good size for Tokyo and spotlessly clean. The staff was courteous and spoke excellent English. As for the location, it is literally a 2 minute walk from Ginza dori, the main street in Ginza, a very posh district in Tokyo full of designer shops, eateries and neon lights at night.
reviews.title: great hotel choice

likes.disliked: — design of bathroom difficult for mobility impaired

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed January 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I was not familiar with the size of rooms in Japan, but became aquainted real quick. The room we were in was about 1/3 size less than the eqivalent in the US. So it was cozy. But for the price, it was worth it and got the job done. It's located in the heart of the Ginza district, so there's a lot of stores and restaurants in the area. In fact, we were right around the corner from a Starbucks, if you need that fix. The staff was courteous, spoke English and overall, we had a good experience.
reviews.title: Small but great location

reviews.text: Just stayed here for 5 nights and would highly recommend this hotel. We locked in a great rate on expedia and was very surprised at the quality. Extremely clean and in a highly central location in Ginza. Staff were friendly and mostly spoke English extremely well. We asked the staff to book us into particular restaurants and mail a package home for us with no problem. I didn't find the rooms too small - compact yes but not overly small. They change the sheets, towels and kimonos everyday unless asked otherwise (e.g. to be more environmentally friendly). The only minor downside is that the hotel is not located on the Yamanote line and it involves a 10 mins walk to the nearest Yamanote line station (Yurakucho). Our room also had free internet connection.
reviews.title: Great comfortable hotel in a good location

reviews.text: One of the few hotels I found in Japan that allowed one child in up to 16 to stay free. We booked a Superior 2 single beds. I was a little concern, since our daughter is a tall 13 years old, but to our suprise the beds were more like a full size bed and the two of us could share one bed comfortably. The room was big enough for the three of us and our luggage. Bathroom was spacious for Japan standards. It took a little getting use to the step up into the bathroom. Lots of neat features through out the room for example, you have to place your key card in a holder near the door to active the lights, so when you leave and take your card out all the lights go off! The rest you can explore when you are in the room.
reviews.title: Kid stayed free!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Service was great. Room was immaculate. Bedding was very comforatble. They were very responsive when I emailed them questions prior to our arrival.
reviews.title: Romantic hotel if you don't like the typical business looking ones

reviews.text: Direct access to Ginzaitchōme Station Exit No. 11 on the Metro Yurakucho Line . You need your key card to access your floor in the elevator, so it's very secure. Only a block or two away from all the department stores. Tsukiji was walking distance maybe a leisure 20 minutes, It's a great way to walk up an appetite for sushi breakfast! We just took a chance with one of the resturants and it was great! Sorry can't give you the name or directions, it's a maze in there.
reviews.title: Great value in the heart of Tokyo

description: Mercure Tokyo Ginza is located in the heart of the city’s most famous shopping and commercial districts, and offers a distinctive French flair and ambiance combined with state-of-the-art technology. The hotel is directly connected to exit 11 of the Ginza Itchome station on the Yurakucho (Y19) subway line. Close-by is Ginza station connected to the Marunouchi (M16), Ginza (G09), and Hibiya (H08) subway lines. Connections from Narita Airport can be made either by taking the limousine bus to Tokyo City Air Terminal (T-CAT) and then 10 minutes by taxi or JR Narita Express to Tokyo station and then 5 minutes by taxi. Guests flying into Haneda Airport should use the Keisei line to Higashi Ginza that is a 5 minute walk from the hotel.
